misconceptions.name: Program does not implement the required grade calculator
misconceptions.description: Instead of implementing a grade-to-letter mapping as specified, the student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points, suggesting a misunderstanding of the need to follow the exact problem specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: As long as my Java program compiles, reads some numeric input, and prints a calculated result, it can be used as an answer, even if it solves a different problem than the one described.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For each programming problem, the solution must match the given specification: the inputs, the processing (logic), and the outputs all need to correspond to what the problem asks. Here, the program should read a single grade value (0–100), use conditional statements to determine which range it falls into, and output the correct letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Prompts ask for x1, y1, x2, and y2 instead of asking for a numeric grade.
Four double inputs are read instead of one grade value.
The computation uses the distance formula between two points.
The output message reports a distance, not a letter grade.
No conditional (if/else) logic appears in the program at all.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused or confused code from a previous distance-formula exercise, or did not carefully read and translate the problem specification into a plan before coding. This indicates a misunderstanding that each problem requires a tailored solution that aligns with the specific requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Before coding, restate the problem in your own words and outline the steps: what input is needed, what decisions need to be made, and what output is required. For this question, plan to (1) declare a variable to hold a single grade; (2) read that value from the user; (3) write an if–else-if chain that checks the grade against the ranges 90–100, 80–89, 70–79, 60–69; and (4) use an else for grades below 60 and print the appropriate letter. Avoid copying unrelated code from other exercises without fully adapting it to the new specification.
related_concepts: Translating a word problem into input/processing/output
Mapping numeric ranges to categorical outputs
Test planning based on expected sample runs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the submitted code—prompts, variables, computation, and output—matches a standard distance-between-two-points problem and contains no elements of a grade calculator (no grade variable, no conditional logic, no letter output). This strongly indicates the student is not addressing the given specification.

evidence.note: All input prompts and calculations are about point coordinates and distance, not about reading a numeric grade and mapping it to a letter grade as required.

misconceptions.name: Complete Task Mismatch
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that calculates the distance between two points instead of implementing the required letter grade calculator. The code addresses an entirely different programming goal.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this code satisfies the requirements for Q3, or they mistakenly submitted a solution intended for a different, likely prior, assignment (the distance formula problem).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem required reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using conditional logic (if/else if/else) to map that grade to a letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Program prompts for four coordinate inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade.
Program calculates distance using the distance formula (Math.sqrt).
Program outputs a numeric distance instead of a letter grade.
No conditional logic (if/else) is present to perform the grading required by the task.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely procedural error (submitting the wrong code file for Q3) or a complete misunderstanding of the problem prompt, confusing it with an earlier coordinate geometry problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt for Q3. You need to implement the grade calculation logic using conditional statements (if, else if, else) based on the specified grade ranges, not the distance formula.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted Java code explicitly implements the distance formula and prompts for four coordinate inputs, confirming it is unrelated to the Grade Calculator problem.

evidence.note: The entire core logic of the program calculates point distance, which is irrelevant to the Grade Calculator Q3 prompt.

misconceptions.name: Complete task misalignment - solving wrong problem
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to calculate the distance between two points using the Euclidean distance formula, rather than a grade calculator that reads a numeric grade and outputs a letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a distance calculation problem, not realizing the assignment asks for a grade calculator.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment Q3 requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and mapping it to a letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on specified ranges. The code should use conditional statements (if/else) to check grade ranges and output the corresponding letter.
symptoms: Program reads four numeric inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade
Program calculates Euclidean distance instead of determining letter grade
Output is a decimal distance value, not a letter grade
Completely different problem being solved than what was assigned
misconceptions.root_cause: The student may have copied code from a different assignment or lab exercise (likely a distance calculation problem) without carefully reading the Q3 requirements. This suggests insufficient problem comprehension before coding.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start by re-reading the problem statement carefully. The program should: (1) Read ONE numeric grade using Scanner, (2) Use if/else statements to check which range (90-100, 80-89, 70-79, 60-69, or below 60) the grade falls into, (3) Output the corresponding letter grade. Consider using nested if-else or if-else if chains.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code solves a completely different problem (Euclidean distance) than what Q3 asks for (grade calculator). There is no overlap in logic, input requirements, or output format.

evidence.note: Code reads four coordinate values and calculates Euclidean distance, which is completely unrelated to reading a grade and outputting a letter grade as required by Q3.

misconceptions.name: Implemented distance formula instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points instead of implementing the required grade-to-letter conversion using conditionals.
misconceptions.student_belief: I believe that for this question I need to read coordinates for two points and print the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program must read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 and use conditional statements to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F). No distance calculation or coordinate input is required.
symptoms: The program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade.
No variable representing a grade is declared or read.
There is no if/else or other conditional logic to check grade ranges.
The output prints a distance value instead of a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely misread the problem statement or reused a previous solution about computing the distance between two points, without aligning the program design to the current specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the distance-related code and start from the problem description: read one numeric grade, then write an if/else-if/else chain that checks which range (90–100, 80–89, etc.) the grade falls into and prints the corresponding letter.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the code is about distance between two points; there is no mention of grades or letters, strongly indicating they implemented the wrong problem.

evidence.note: All input/output and computation are about two points and their distance; there is no handling of a numeric grade or letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misunderstanding of Problem Requiring Distance Calculation
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two points (four inputs), rather than a grade calculator (one input) as required by the prompt.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task required calculating the distance between two points, or they copied code from a previous unrelated assignment and submitted it for this problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task explicitly required reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and calculating the corresponding letter grade using conditional logic.
symptoms: Code reads four double inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one integer grade.
Code performs distance calculation using Math.sqrt and geometric formula.
Output prints a distance value instead of a letter grade.
Complete omission of conditional statements (if/else if/else) needed for grading.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the prompt, submitting the wrong file, or confusing the current problem with a past exercise (like calculating distance).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the problem statement carefully. The purpose of this program is to calculate a letter grade based on a single numeric input, not the distance between points. Delete all code related to coordinate geometry and start by reading one integer input for the grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code implements the distance formula exactly and takes four inputs, proving it addresses a different problem entirely.

evidence.note: Input is taken for two coordinates, not a single grade input (0-100).
The core logic calculates geometric distance, which is irrelevant to grading.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+distance);
evidence.note: The required output is a letter grade, but the output generated is a distance value.

misconceptions.name: Wrong problem submitted / Problem misidentification
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a complete solution to a different problem (distance calculator) rather than the assigned grade calculator task. This suggests either significant misunderstanding of the assignment or a critical copy-paste error.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task is to calculate the distance between two coordinate points, not to convert numeric grades to letter grades.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The Q3 task requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on specific range thresholds, using conditional logic to check grade ranges.
symptoms: Code prompts for coordinates, not a grade
Distance formula appears instead of conditional grade checking
Output displays distance, not letter grade
No if/else or switch statements for grade mapping
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may have copy-pasted code from a previous assignment, misread the problem statement, or submitted code from the wrong file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start fresh with this assignment. Read through the problem statement carefully. You need to: (1) use Scanner to read ONE numeric grade, (2) use if/else statements to check which range it falls in, and (3) print the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The mismatch between submitted code and assignment requirements is unambiguous. The code solves a completely different problem with no overlap in logic or I/O with the grade calculator.

evidence.note: Student reads coordinates (x1, y1) instead of a single numeric grade value

evidence.snippet:
double distance=Math.sqrt((x2-x1)*(x2-x1)+(y2-y1)*(y2-y1));
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+distance);
evidence.note: Calculates and outputs Euclidean distance; should instead map numeric grade to letter grade using conditionals
